#Text=Bush starts off Africa trip in Benin
#Text=Saturday , February 16 , 2008

#Text=U.S. President George W. Bush , accompanied by his wife Laura , began his five-nation trip to Africa today in Benin , where he met with President Yayi Boni and participated in a joint press conference .
#Text=This is Bush 's second visit to Africa and the first time any US president has visited Benin .
#Text=Topics that were discussed included malaria , cotton , and the crises in Kenya and Darfur .

#Text=At the press conference , held at Cadjehoun International Airport in Cotonou , Yayi thanked Bush for coming to visit and praised him for his " great concern for Africa , its well being , and of the development of its people . "

column1: #Text=Bush then commended the government of Benin for their " fight against corruption " and " firm commitment to the investment in its people " .

column1: #Text=" Your fight against corruption is visible and easy for the people to see , " Bush said .

#Text=" This is such a good lesson ... because leaders around the world have got to understand that the United States wants to partner with leaders and the people , but we 're not going to do so with people that steal money , pure and simple . "
#Text=Benin is one of the recipients of the Millennium Challenge Account , which aims to foster economic growth in countries that are deemed to have effective governments and economic freedom .
#Text=On the topic of malaria , Bush mentioned the Malaria Initiative , which intends to provide a mosquito net for every child to prevent the spread of the disease .
#Text=He also mentioned initiatives to facilitate the spread of HIV and AIDS .
#Text=" We can save lives with an aggressive , comprehensive strategy , " Bush said .
#Text=" And that 's exactly what you 're putting in place here in Benin . "
#Text=The United States wants to partner with leaders and the people , but we 're not going to do so with people that steal money , pure and simple . — George W. Bush
#Text=The economy was also an important issue .
#Text=President Yayi said he and President Bush discussed diversifying Benin 's economy away from its dependence on cotton .
#Text=" He shared his vision with us , and he is encouraging us to diversify the sources of solutions to the problem that we have today , namely the cotton industry . "
#Text=Yayi says it is hard competing with cotton markets in Asia and the United States .
#Text=Bush said the World Trade Organization is willing to help Benin 's economy , but he also suggested exporting more cotton-based products in addition to raw cotton .
#Text=Bush said the United States will help facilitate a peacekeeping force in Darfur , but will not send troops to the region .
#Text=" I made the decision not to [ send troops ] , upon the recommendation of a lot of the groups involved in Darfur , as well as other folks ...

column3:

#Text=When asked about the situation in Kenya , Bush said he has sent Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to visit the country on Monday to support former UN Secretary General Kofi Annan in mediating the conflict .

#Text= Kenya is an issue ... and that 's why I 'm sending Secretary Rice there to help the Kofi Annan initiative - all aimed at having a clear message that there be no violence and that there ought to be a power-sharing agreement , " said Bush .

column1: #Text=White House national security adviser Stephen Hadley said Rice 's visit will only last a few hours .
#Text=" It 's basically to go in , give some impetus , but then step out and let Kofi Annan continue his diplomacy , " he said .
#Text=At a press briefing aboard Air Force One , one reporter questioned what could be accomplished in a few hours and asked why the President did n't go to Kenya instead .
#Text=Ambassador Jendayi Frazer answered with , " Secretary Rice 's engagement on Kenya has been much longer than a few hours .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= The purpose of her going is to back Kofi 's mediation , it 's not to take over that mediation , " Frazer continued .

column1: #Text=" President Bush does not need to go to Kenya at this point .

#Text=At the right moment in time , the President will engage , but right now it 's occurring in a very systematic way to back Annan 's mediation , not to try to supplant Annan 's mediation .
